description.plain:
Now based in San Francisco, California, Thao & The Get Down Stay Down are an alternative folk rock band that started in Falls Church, Virginia, with their first album Like the Linen in 2005.

Thao Nguyen is the band’s lead vocalist and plays guitar; Adam Thompson does backing vocals and plays guitar, bass, and keyboard; Charlie Glenn plays guitar and piano; Jason Slota plays drums; and Johanna Kunin does backing vocals and plays piano.

The band have released five studio albums;
Like the Linen – 2005
We Brave Bee Stings and All – 2008
Know Better Learn Faster – 2009
We the Common – 2013
A Man Alive – 2016

description.plain:
From NPR:
“At the heart of its lyrics, Thao told me, is a ‘reclamation of the body.’ It’s a song for survivors of sexual violence, a catchy chorus cloaked around a driven beat, which [in the music video] sees Thao dressed and dancing sharply — in a purple paisley jumpsuit.


Never have I felt more energized or connected or grateful onstage than in the performance of this song. I have loved nothing more, nor have I ever felt more honored, than to share very raw and heartfelt moments with people to whom this song has meant something.

I’ve danced a lot more than I expected while performing ‘Meticulous Bird’ onstage, that’s why I wanted to dance in the video. I’ve never performed it live in a purple paisley jumpsuit, but the jumpsuit is part of the being free. I’ve never had such an emotive outlet via song as I have in this one — that is demonstrated in my straight-to-camera moments.

Director Jonny Look gave me the opportunity to present the song in all its facets: the darkness, the dark humor, the unfettered anger and the complexities of moving on from violation and how the memory of trespass rises to the fore and then recedes into the every day.

My ongoing hope for ‘Meticulous Bird’ is that a survivor of any kind would hear it and want to use it; to celebrate their sovereignty, to remind themselves of their power, to warn those who would exploit the vulnerabilities of others that such trespasses against the humanity of one or many will never go unanswered. My updated, amended hope for ‘Meticulous Bird’ is that it is just one contribution of an endless many in the efforts to resist and to notify whoever needs notifying: you have no idea how ferocious we can and will be."

description.plain:
This is the title track on Thao and TGDSD’s album of the same name. Valerie Bolden is the name of an inmate that Thao met on her first advocacy visit to a California prison. In the intro to this video, Thao descibes how their simple, human conversation and a drive to “collect or harness some collective energy” drove her to write this song.

In addition to regular touring performances, she has since played the song at a rally in support of incarcerated Californians: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-YDcqW9PwO0

description.plain:
“Nobody Dies” was the first single from A Man Alive. In a performance at KEXP, Thao recounts a conversation with a friend who was similarly estranged from her father. Her friend’s father was sick and she was thinking of resuming contact with him after many years. This might be their last chance to patch things up.

While the looming death of her father made Thao’s friend inclined to put aside her anger, Thao still sounds angry on this song. How could her father not reach out to her for years when death will soon make their estrangement permanent? All parties are acting like nobody dies.

description.plain:
On March 19th 2020, via the band’s Instagram page (@thaogetstaydown), Thao Nguyen had this to say about Temple;
“In 2015, our band went to Vietnam and I took my mom. I had never been and she hadn’t been back in over 40 years. While we were in Vietnam, she very uncharacteristically addressed the war. She said to me: you have to learn for yourself what freedom is, why millions of people would risk their lives for it. I am almost certain she was not encouraging me to be publicly out but for my intents and purposes she was grudgingly saying do what you have to do.

I wrote this song in my mom’s voice, celebrating her life before, during, and after war, and, most importantly, blessing my pursuit of my own happiness and freedom in this life that is a gift.

My parents are refugees of war. I have at times subscribed to the exclusive narrative of refugee sacrifice, abject loss and grief; those are there too, but they are not the only things. My mom is light and joyful and she has always loved dancing. The performers in this music video were enlisted from community dance groups in the Vietnamese diaspora in Orange County, California. My favorite part of this video is when the dancers let loose. I see them let loose and I think of people’s capacity to experience everything at once, I think of my mom’s capacity for joy, I think of our whole extended family’s capacity for joy and reinvention, and I cry every time.

Part of my mission in writing this song was to honor and celebrate my mom’s entire journey, to afford her the luxury of a complex humanity and history. And to remind myself that anyone who is free and safe is free and safe by sheer collision of various fortunes. This song is a small effort in service of a larger hope: that in taking care to communicate a person’s life, you help foster respect for people’s lives. To celebrate, care and advocate for someone is to not reduce them. To reduce someone is to get dangerously close to dehumanizing them. Thank you to all those who work to honor the dignity of people seeking freedom and safety.

The other part of my mission was to claim my own freedom. The opportunity to be free takes different shapes, makes different demands on different generations. I was raised by and for tradition and reverence that exist outside time. Some of the traditions I have honored and adored, some have been like a foot on my neck. I love the people and culture I come from and I have always operated as though I owe them everything. I owe them a great deal, but I do not owe them the denial of my full life. To avoid being publicly out for the perceived comfort of a family and community is to remove yourself from their life and your own. I believe I can belong to myself and still belong to them.

It has taken me a long time; I see now- especially now- our task is to save our allegiance for each other and leave none for fear. Bury the burden, baby.“
https://www.instagram.com/p/B97OioDhT8J/?utm_source=ig_web_button_share_sheet

description.plain:
“Astonished Man” finds Thao Nguyen regretting past behaviors and lamenting over the lack of a relationship with her estranged father.



The song kicks off with a drum beat from the band’s drummer Jason Slota and is followed by chopped vocals, as assisted by Merrill Garbus, and leads to the song’s chorus, where Thao is found singing about trying to be a better person, as a thick synth bass line jumps between the background and foreground. Merrill Garbus of tUnE-yArDs, who produced the album which the song belongs to, A Man Alive, plays flute on the song.

In an interview on the Song Exploder podcast, Nguyen described Garbus' role as “imperative”:

I had an idea that this record would be very personal and I couldn’t have done it without a very good friend at the helm. She knows me very well and knows my history with my dad. Sonically, Merrill embodies this kind of fearlessness and raw energy and that kind of fearlessness I wanted to tap into.

In the same interview, Nguyen described the song’s inspiration and meaning:

When I wrote this song, the first lyric I wrote is at the beginning and end of the song: I must find and capture an astonished man, which in part is inspired by Marilynne Robinson’s writing is one who would be astonished with the amount of forgiveness that could be afforded him, that kind of astonishment that in the end people would still come looking for him and want apart of him, and he is convinced that he is undeserving of such.

Nguyen is referencing the following line from Marilynne Robinson’s novel Gilead:

I said, “We all love you, you know,” and he laughed and said, “You’re all saints.” He stopped in the door and lifted his hat, and then he was gone, God bless him.



Nguyen concludes on the song’s meaning and the writing process' cathartic nature:

There’s melancholy in this song and there’s some sadness and grief but there’s an optimism in this kind of new-found forgiveness. The greatest service of this record was to grieve, to acknowledge the kind of pain I felt for my whole life and to just admit it, to go in there and talk about it, to write about it, sing about it,  and have it on record. Making this record forced me to do that and I’m so grateful to it.

description.plain: In this song, Thao writes what her absent father might be thinking and feeling. She images that he regrets what he’s done, wishes he’d been a better father, and wants to pay for what he’s done, because he want to have a relationship with her. It’s only in the last line that she switches back to her own voice, confronting the fact that even if he does feel the way she describes in this song, she still doesn’t know if “how [does he] save, [he’s] so much to pay for”.

description.plain: Thao Nguyen wrote “City” as a tribute to her activist friends and the Occupy demonstrations in Oakland, California. In this article, Thao elaborates on how the demonstrations made her feel energized, thinking “‘If I lay still through this, shame if I sleep tonight’”.

description.plain: Thao’s feelings of betrayal, blame, anger, and hurt towards her father who left her when she was young, expressed often earlier in the album, take a turn in this song. Here, she finds peace in forgiveness upon (possibly?) meeting him again and believing that he truly tried his best, as flawed as he was and as much pain as he caused her. They have grown and she hopes for peaceful understanding and closure at last. Her feelings remain conflicted, however.

description.plain:
Thao posted their feelings and the process of Pure Cinema on May 11th 2020, via the band’s Instagram page (@thaogetstaydown):-

“Pure Cinema is such full band song, and it has so much to do with our years of touring as a roving family constellation, that I really wanted this video to highlight and celebrate The Get Down Stay Down. However much of a fraction I have been out there over the years, our band and crew kept me as safe and sane as was possible. They have been my stabilizing force for so long. As it goes with family I don’t know if I’ve ever truly thanked them or told them. It was so sweet and also quite bittersweet to see everyone at home, projected into our home. I don’t know when we can play shows together again, I don’t know what touring will look like. I miss the band.⁣
⁣
Pure Cinema is about taking stock of how adrift I’ve been, in every sense of the word. It’s very easy to feel lost and alone even as you are surrounded by people. I’ve had a very compromised relationship to touring over the years.. if you’re not right with yourself it is only going to be exaggerated as you cast yourself out into the world. I’ve floated above my life for a long time; I’ve landed now. It makes me so happy to see my bandmates settled and happy in their own homes and lives, as I am in mine. Pure Cinema is a cautionary tale and also an encouragement to keep faith and keep building home and family.”

https://www.instagram.com/p/CADN5FIhxm4/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link

description.plain: Thao’s mother raised her and her brother alone after her husband left, while also running a laundromat. In this song, written from her mother’s point of view, Thao acknowledges all of her mother’s sacrifices and hard work and thanks her.
